text: Improvement pill here in the mid 20th
century two groundbreaking experiments
on motivation were conducted a
psychology professor at the University
of Wisconsin tested the problem solving
skills of eight monkeys by giving them
puzzles to solve the monkeys enjoyed
solving puzzles by the end of the
experiment they could solve them pretty
quickly the experiment was curious to
know why the monkeys cared about solving
the puzzles they didn't get a reward for
their efforts they seemed just to enjoy
it for its own sake so the professor
tried rewarding the monkeys with raisins
for completing the puzzles given the
leading theories of motivation at the
time he presumed their problem solving
would improve but they actually got much
worse and gave up more quickly how could
this be two decades later another study
picked up where this one left off this
time on humans The experimenter Divided
subjects into two groups group a and
Group B and made them solve puzzles
first both groups had to solve the
puzzles for their own enjoyment and
could spend as long as they wanted they
weren't given external rewards both
groups solved the puzzle in around $3 4
minutes next group a was paid a small
amount of money to solve the puzzles and
Group B wasn't as you'd expect group a
became more interested and spent over 5
minutes working on the puzzles before
they got bored Group B behaved the same
as before however the final session
produced unexpected results again like
before neither group was paid for the
task but this time group a spent
significantly less time on the puzzles
before giving up about 2 minutes without
the money they were less interested in
contrast Group B spent more time showing
they were becoming naturally more
interested in the puzzles without
needing rewards in his groundbreaking
book on motivation Drive author Daniel
pink argues that hidden in these
experiments is a profound truth about
human nature here lies the answer to why
some of us get so much done and why
others procrastinate and delay letting
their dreams go unfulfilled increasingly
science is telling us how to activate
the motivational parts of our brain to
unlock the drive we need to do big
things many of us think we're lazy but
we're actually just looking for
motivation in the wrong place according
to Daniel pink there are two kinds of
motivation two fuel sources the first is
extrinsic motivation extrinsic
motivation is about doing things because
of the reward we get or the punishment
we avoid not because we naturally want
to it's about external factors
influencing our actions typical
extrinsic motivators are money status
prizes and expensive things we can show
up off look around you extrinsic
motivation is everywhere at school if
you study hard and do what you're told
you get a good grade if you don't you
get a bad grade or detention at work if
you do a good job you get a raise or a
promotion if you don't you get fired
this is the basic framework if you do X
you get y the reward and Punishment are
separate from the action so what's wrong
with extrinsic motivation well it can
work sometimes but it's not sustain
stainable and generally only works in
the short term imagine extrinsic
motivation as a spark that lights a fire
with gasoline the gasoline rewards
creates a quick intense flame but it
burns out rapidly once the fuel is used
up the fire needs constant refueling to
keep burning and just like extrinsic
motivation once the gasoline runs out
the fire dies we get used to extrinsic
rewards the feeling of earning a treat
or getting a raise doesn't feel as good
the more of them we get over time
external motivators lose their power
leaving us wondering why we feel so
unmotivated this is a problem as so much
of our world relies on external rewards
now contrast this with intrinsic
motivation the second fuel source this
is more like a campfire built with solid
slow burning logs the fire might take
longer to start but once it's burning it
gives us a steady long- lasting energy
source doesn't need constant refueling
from the outside like intrinsic
motivation that comes from within us the
logs keep the fire burning sustainably
over time in your life intrinsic
motivation will come from working hard
on a project just because you want to
not for the reward you might get when
you do something just because of what
you learn how it makes you feel or the
sense of fulfillment it brings you're
experiencing intrinsic motivation maybe
you're playing an instrument simply to
get better at it volunteering just to
help others or working out just because
you enjoy it and how it makes you feel
we all know what it's like to experience
intrinsic motivation as young children
we play build things and go on
adventures for no reason other than our
curiosity Daniel pinks three methods for
helping us unlock our intrinsic
motivation three legs of the intrinsic
motivation stool the first is autonomy
think about all the great artists
scientists and inventors of History
Einstein Da Vinci Picasso they didn't
succeed in their fields and changeed the
world because they had someone telling
them when to work what to work on and
who to work with no it'd be crazy if
they did and you're no different Drive
teaches us that there are four T's of
autonomy time task technique and team
when we have a say over when we work
what we work on how we do it and who we
work with we perform at our best
remember a time when you tackled the
task your way or were allowed to take
complete ownership of something without
someone watching controlling and
micromanaging you the whole time maybe
you let a presentation at school or were
given some freedom in your job to work
on an interesting side project you
remember how alive you felt and how
motivated you were to do a good job this
is autonomy in action it's why many of
the best products produced by big tech
companies like Google like Gmail and
Google News were invented by employees
during some special time they were given
to work on whatever they wanted our
brains are wired to thrive and make us
feel good when we have control over our
work we're naturally self-driven
autonomy brings out the best in US the
second component is Mastery Mastery is
about getting better at something you
care about and being recognized for your
accomplishments if you've ever got
really into a sport or hobby because of
how excited you were to see your skills
improving you've experienced Mastery
Mastery releases neurochemicals that
boost our mood to achieve Mastery we
need to deliberately practice by making
a conscious effort to improve at
something we need to get feedback from
others and we need to be consistent
showing up again and again despite
setback
the secret to Mastery is choosing tasks
in what Daniel pink calls the Goldilocks
zone we don't want to pick something so
hard that we can't do it and give up we
don't want to choose a task so easy that
it never pushes us to improve we want to
be in the middle being in the goldilock
zone triggers a flow State this is the
state that makes us feel most alive and
motivated to keep working on our
projects just cuz we want to flow is one
of the most powerful keys for unlocking
intrinsic motivation this is actually
why video games are so addictive they're
perfectly designed by expert Engineers
to challenge us just enough to keep us
playing but not so much that we struggle
and give up in the real world it's less
straightforward but we can always make
sure at work and school that we're
moving outside our comfort zones enough
to become masters of a craft the final
leg in the stool is purpose Drive
teaches us that purpose is about the
desire to do things that don't only
benefit us they also serve something
larger than ourselves you might have had
jobs that you were good at and gave you
extrinsic rewards like a high salary but
something felt off there was no bigger
purpose your job felt like a bunch of
meaningless tasks we spend a good chunk
of our lives at work we want that time
to matter Daniel pink says that the
drive to make the world a better place
to make a difference explains why some
entrepreneurs decide to make less money
so that their businesses can help more
people it's why people give up
high-paying jobs to work for a nonprofit
or volunteer overseas as an intrinsic
motivator purpose pushes us to achieve
things that extrinsic rewards like money
and job promotions never could it helps
us stick with something and overcome
challenges in a way that nothing else
can your purpose can be anything you
choose maybe you want to help others
maybe you want to provide for your
family maybe you want to become the best
version of yourself but whatever it is
it has to be true to you if you want to
unlock its power as a motivator to work
hard and achieve your dreams the way
we're taught that motivation works is
wrong and outdated using these insights
from the new science of motivation from
Daniel Pink's drive you can tap into the
sources of motivation used by the
world's top performers and supercharge
your productivity hope you found this
useful I'll see you on the next one
[Music]
